title: Aircraft with Selectively Attachable Passenger Pod Assembly

events.title: Application filed by Bell Helicopter Textron Inc
Assigned to BELL HELICOPTER TEXTRON INC.
description: ASSIGNMENT OF ASSIGNORS INTEREST (SEE DOCUMENT FOR DETAILS).
Assignors: OLDROYD, PAUL K., McCULLOUGH, John Richard

classifications.description: Aircraft capable of landing or taking-off vertically, e.g. vertical take-off and landing [VTOL] aircraft having its flight directional axis horizontal when grounded the lift during taking-off being created by free or ducted propellers or by blowers the propellers being tiltable relative to the fuselage
Parts of fuselage relatively movable to improve pilots view
Severable or jettisonable parts of fuselage facilitating emergency escape
Collapsible or foldable blades
Aircraft stabilisation not otherwise provided for by gravity or inertia-actuated apparatus
Compound rotorcraft, i.e. aircraft using in flight the features of both aeroplane and rotorcraft characterised by provision of fixed wings
Compound rotorcraft, i.e. aircraft using in flight the features of both aeroplane and rotorcraft with forward-propulsion propellers pivotable to act as lifting rotors
Aircraft capable of landing or taking-off vertically, e.g. vertical take-off and landing [VTOL] aircraft having its flight directional axis vertical when grounded
Aircraft not otherwise provided for characterised by special use of the remote controlled vehicle type, i.e. RPV
Aircraft not otherwise provided for having multiple wings
Parachutes in association with aircraft, e.g. for braking thereof
Ejectable capsules
Aircraft characterised by the type or position of power plants of gas-turbine type  within, or attached to, wings
Flying platforms with five or more distinct rotor axes, e.g. octocopters
Wings
Foldable or collapsible rotors or rotor supports
Navigation or guidance aids for take-off
Navigation or guidance aids for approach or landing
Navigation or guidance aids for a single aircraft
Navigation or guidance aids for unmanned aircraft
Modular constructions of airplanes or helicopters
Compound rotorcraft, i.e. aircraft using in flight the features of both aeroplane and rotorcraft with provision for reducing drag of inoperative rotor

UAVs specially adapted for particular uses or applications for life-saving or rescue operations; for medical use for bringing emergency supplies to persons or animals in danger, e.g. ropes or life vests
UAVs specially adapted for particular uses or applications for transporting passengers; for transporting goods other than weapons
UAVs characterised by their flight controls autonomous, i.e. by navigating independently from ground or air stations, e.g. by using inertial navigation systems [INS]
Remote controls
Propulsion using internal combustion piston engines
Thrust vectoring
Propulsion using electrically powered motors
Undercarriages with landing legs
Vertical take-off or landing, e.g. using rockets using parachutes, balloons or the like

abstract: In some embodiments, an aircraft includes a flying frame having an airframe, a propulsion system attached to the airframe and a flight control system operably associated with the propulsion system wherein, the flying frame has a vertical takeoff and landing mode and a forward flight mode. A pod assembly is selectively attachable to the flying frame such that the flying frame is rotatable about the pod assembly wherein, the pod assembly remains in a generally horizontal attitude during vertical takeoff and landing, forward flight and transitions therebetween.
claims:
1. An aircraft comprising:
a flying frame including an airframe, a propulsion system attached to the airframe and a flight control system operably associated with the propulsion system; and a pod assembly selectively attachable to the flying frame, wherein, the flying frame has a vertical takeoff and landing mode and a forward flight mode; and wherein, the flying frame is rotatable about the pod assembly such that the pod assembly remains in a generally horizontal attitude during vertical takeoff and landing, forward flight and transitions therebetween.
2. The aircraft as recited in claim 1 wherein the airframe further comprises first and second wing members having a plurality of pylons extending therebetween.

3. The aircraft as recited in claim 2 wherein, in the vertical takeoff and landing mode, the first wing member is forward of the pod assembly and the second wing member is aft of the pod assembly and wherein, in the forward flight mode, the first wing member is below the pod assembly and the second wing member is above the pod assembly.

4. The aircraft as recited in claim 2 wherein, in the vertical takeoff and landing mode, the first and second wing members are above the pod assembly and wherein, in the forward flight mode, the first wing member is below the pod assembly and the second wing member is above the pod assembly.
5. The aircraft as recited in claim 2 wherein the pod assembly is rotatably mounted between pylons of the flying frame.

6. The aircraft as recited in claim 1 wherein, in the forward flight mode, the pod assembly is operable to translate in forward and aft directions relative to the flying frame such that the center of gravity of the aircraft is adjustable.

7. The aircraft as recited in claim 1 wherein the pod assembly and the flying frame have at least one communication channel therebetween operable to enable communication between the pod assembly and the flight control system of the flying frame.
8. The aircraft as recited in claim 1 wherein the pod assembly further comprises a manned pod assembly.
9. The aircraft as recited in claim 1 wherein the pod assembly further comprises an unmanned pod assembly.
10. The aircraft as recited in claim 1 wherein the flying frame is operable to jettison the pod assembly during flight.

11. The aircraft as recited in claim 10 wherein the pod assembly further comprises a parachute operable to be deployed in association with the pod assembly being jettisoned from the flying frame during flight.
12. The aircraft as recited in claim 11 wherein the parachute further comprises a parafoil parachute.
13. The aircraft as recited in claim 10 wherein the pod assembly further comprises a watertight pod assembly.
14. The aircraft as recited in claim 1 wherein the flying frame is operable to couple with and decouple from the pod assembly when the flying frame is positioned on a surface.
15. The aircraft as recited in claim 1 wherein the flying frame is operable to autonomously couple with and decouple from the pod assembly.

16. A method of operating an aircraft comprising:
providing a flying frame including an airframe, a propulsion system attached to the airframe and a flight control system operably associated with the propulsion system; selectively attaching the flying frame to a pod assembly; lifting the pod assembly into the air in a vertical takeoff and landing mode of the aircraft with the pod assembly in a generally horizontal attitude; transitioning the aircraft between the vertical takeoff and landing mode and a forward flight mode by rotating the flying frame relative to the pod assembly while maintaining the pod assembly in the generally horizontal attitude; and transporting the pod assembly in the forward flight mode of the aircraft with the pod assembly in the generally horizontal attitude.

17. The method as recited in claim 16 wherein selectively attaching the flying frame to the pod assembly further comprises rotatably mounting the pod assembly to pylons extending between wing members of the airframe.
18. The method as recited in claim 16 further comprising jettisoning the pod assembly from the flying frame during flight.

19. The method as recited in claim 16 wherein selectively attaching the flying frame to the pod assembly further comprises operably coupling the flying frame to and decoupling the flying from the pod assembly when the flying frame is positioned on a surface.

20. The method as recited in claim 16 wherein selectively attaching the flying frame to the pod assembly further comprises autonomously coupling the flying frame to and decoupling the flying from the pod assembly.
